title: Impact of Icosapent Ethyl on Alzheimers Disease Biomarkers in Preclinical Adults
description_brief: The number of Americans diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease (AD) is expected to triple by 2050. Compared to the general population, Veterans have a greater risk of AD, likely in part due to their increased incidence of traumatic brain injury, post-traumatic stress disorder, depression, and other vascular-related health issues. Based on available data, 423,000 new cases of AD are anticipated in Veterans by 2020. Thus, the discovery of effective therapies to prevent or delay the onset of AD in Veterans is critical. The goal of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of a purified form of the omega-3 fatty acid eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) called icosapent ethyl (IPE), on improving brain blood flow, spinal fluid markers of AD pathology, and cognitive performance in middle-aged, cognitively-healthy Veterans with increased risk of AD. If IPE delays the onset of AD by even 5 years, the incidence of AD would be reduced by 50% in this population and could have a profound effect on Veteran quality of life and healthcare costs.
description_detailed: The proposed study is a proof-of-concept, randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind, parallel-group clinical trial assessing the efficacy of 18 months of icosapent ethyl (IPE) therapy on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), and cognitive biomarkers for AD in 150 cognitively-healthy Veterans ages 50-75 years. The overarching goal of this trial is to assess whether icosapent ethyl beneficially affects intermediate physiological measures associated with onset of AD in order to evaluate whether larger, multi-site, longer-duration Alzheimer's prevention trials are warranted to assess more definitive clinical outcomes. The proposed study aims to: 1) investigate the effects of 18 months of IPE vs. placebo on regional cerebral blood flow as measured by arterial spin-labeling MRI; 2) determine the impact of 18 months of IPE vs. placebo on CSF biomarkers of AD pathology; and 3) evaluate the effects of 18 months of IPE vs. placebo on cognitive performance.

outcomeMeasures.title: Regional Cerebral Blood Flow Using Arterial Spin-labeling MRI
outcomeMeasures.description: For the primary outcome we chose an anatomical region, posterior cingulate gyrus, that aligned with statistical region of interest sensitive to changes in cerebral blood flow in cognitively-unimpaired adults at risk for Alzheimer's disease. Brain blood flow was averaged across the right and left posterior cingulate gyrus.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Analysis sample is intent-to-treat (ITT), ASL values were imputed from baseline values for 23 participants (n=14 IPE and n=9 placebo); 17 participants lacked baseline ASL values (n=9 IPE, n=8 placebo) and could not be included in analyses.

groups.title: Icosapent Ethyl (IPE)
groups.description:
Participants will be randomized in a 1:1 ratio to receive icosapent ethyl 4 g daily vs. matching gel cap placebo

icosapent ethyl (IPE): Participants will be randomized in a 1:1 ratio to receive icosapent ethyl 4 g daily vs. matching gel cap placebo

groups.title: Placebo
groups.description:
Participants will be randomized in a 1:1 ratio to receive icosapent ethyl 4 g daily vs. matching gel cap placebo

gel cap placebo: Participants will be randomized in a 1:1 ratio to receive icosapent ethyl 4 g daily vs. matching gel cap placebo

analyses.groupDescription: The proposed study aims to investigate the effects of 18 months of IPE vs. placebo on regional cerebral blood flow in the bilateral posterior cingulate gyrus as measured by arterial spin-labeling MRI . IPE was hypothesized to improve regional cerebral blood flow over placebo after 18 months.
analyses.pValueComment: ASL values at 18 months were regressed on treatment group (IPE vs placebo) statistically controlling for age at baseline visit and ASL measured at baseline visit.

outcomeMeasures.title: Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) Biomarkers of Alzheimer's Disease
outcomeMeasures.description: CSF beta-amyloid-42, total tau, and phosphorylated tau-181 (Roche Cobas Elecsys e611). Lower CSF beta-amyloid-42 and higher phosphorylated tau-181 or total tau are associated with risk for Alzheimer's disease.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Analysis is based on an intent-to-treat, n=19 participants dropped out prior to receiving an 18 month lumbar puncture (n=11 IPE, n=8 placebo); 26 participants opted out of the lumbar puncture procedure (n=11 IPE, n=15 placebo)

groups.title: Icosapent Ethyl (IPE)
groups.description:
Participants will be randomized in a 1:1 ratio to receive icosapent ethyl 4 g daily vs. matching gel cap placebo

icosapent ethyl (IPE): Participants will be randomized in a 1:1 ratio to receive icosapent ethyl 4 g daily vs. matching gel cap placebo

groups.title: Placebo
groups.description:

analyses.groupDescription: Beta-amyloid(1-42) concentration in CSF was log-transformed prior to analysis to approximate a normal distribution.
analyses.statisticalComment: 18 month Beta-amyloid(1-42) was regressed on group (IPE vs placebo) and covariates age at baseline visit and Beta-amyloid(1-42) at baseline visit.
analyses.estimateComment: Placebo group is the reference group.

analyses.groupDescription: Phosphorylated tau (pTau181) measured in CSF was log-transformed prior to analysis to approximate a normal distribution.
analyses.statisticalComment: log-transformed 18 month pTau181 was regressed on group (IPE vs placebo) and covariates age at baseline and log-transformed ptau181at baseline visit.
analyses.estimateComment: Placebo group is the reference group.

analyses.groupDescription: Total tau was log-transformed prior to analysis to better approximate a normal distribution.
analyses.pValueComment: 18 months total Tau was regressed on Group (IPE vs placebo) and covariates age at baseline and total Tau at baseline.
analyses.estimateComment: Placebo group was the reference group.

outcomeMeasures.title: Cognitive Performance
outcomeMeasures.description: Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study Preclinical Alzheimer's Cognitive Composite (ADCS-PACC). Composite scores at each time point are standardize to baseline values such that at baseline the mean=0 and the standard deviation = 1. Standardized scores range from -3.15 to 3.09. Higher scores indicate better cognition.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Analyses were conducted on an intent-to-treat basis. 19 participants dropped out prior to month 18 study visit (n=11 IPE, n=8)

groups.title: Icosapent Ethyl (IPE)
groups.description:
Participants will be randomized in a 1:1 ratio to receive icosapent ethyl 4 g daily vs. matching gel cap placebo

gel cap placebo: Participants will be randomized in a 1:1 ratio to receive icosapent ethyl 4 g daily vs. matching gel cap placebo

analyses.groupDescription: Four cognitive tests were standardized (baseline mean and standard deviation) prior to averaging to create the ADCS Preclinical Alzheimer Cognitive Composite (ADCS-PACC) score. The final composite score was standardized again using baseline mean and standard deviation (range -3.15 to 3.10). Higher scores indicate better cognitive performance. A linear mixed effects model was used to determine if change in ADCS-PACC composite scores was modified by treatment group.
analyses.statisticalComment: Covariates included education level, gender, and age at baseline visit.
analyses.estimateComment: Placebo group was the reference group.

adverseEventsModule.description: Participants were assessed for adverse events at months 1, 3, 6, 9, 12, 15, and 18.

seriousEvents.notes: Participant passed away after falling down a staircase.
Participant was hospitalized after COPD attack
Participant was admitted to hospital after presenting chest tightness
Participant had planned surgery for prostate cancer.
Participant admitted after presenting to hospital with heart palpitations.
Participant admitted to hospital after an aortic aneurysm
Participant hospitalized after developing spontaneous pneumothorax.
Participant hospitalized after presenting with neck pain and inability to swallow.
Participant presented to the hospital after a fall.
Participant was admitted to hospital after developing a UTI.
Participant hospitalized after presenting with high blood pressure.

otherEvents.notes: Participant reported headache following an LP
Participant suffered an accidental injury, resolved.

otherEvents.organSystem: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)
otherEvents.notes: Participant had a synovial cyst removed from spine (L4/L5).
Participant reported sweating and itching after starting study drug.
Participant experienced breathing issues related to sinus infection.

limitationsAndCaveats.description: Study sample lacked racial, ethnic and gender diversity. The study was on-going during COVID-19 closures which impacted participants' ability to take part in in-person study procedures.

pointOfContact.title: Cynthia Carlsson, MD, MS; Professor of Medicine (Geriatrics)
pointOfContact.organization: Madison Veterans Affairs Geriatrics Research, Education & Clinical Center (GRECC)

explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is icosapent ethyl (IPE), a purified form of the omega‑3 fatty acid eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA). The study description proposes IPE to improve brain blood flow, cerebrospinal‑fluid markers of AD pathology, and cognitive performance with the aim of preventing or delaying Alzheimer's disease onset — i.e., a disease‑modifying/preventive intent rather than only symptomatic relief. citeturn0search2turn0search0

Act: IPE (VASCEPA) is a small‑molecule/low‑molecular‑weight lipid (an EPA ethyl ester), not a biologic (not a monoclonal antibody or vaccine). Because the trial tests IPE to alter disease biomarkers and delay onset (disease‑modifying/preventive goal), the best fit among the provided categories is 'disease‑targeted small molecule'. Note: IPE's exact mechanisms for CV and potential neuroprotective effects are not fully understood (anti‑inflammatory, lipid/vascular effects are hypothesized). citeturn0search3turn0search0

Reflect: Classification check — IPE is not a biologic, and the trial’s primary intent is prevention/disease modification (biomarkers, delay onset), not only transient cognitive enhancement or treatment of neuropsychiatric symptoms. Although IPE does not directly target amyloid/tau in the way an anti‑amyloid monoclonal would, its use to modify AD risk/biomarkers places it in the 'disease‑targeted small molecule' category rather than 'cognitive enhancer' or 'neuropsychiatric symptom improvement.' Ambiguity: if one required a direct molecular anti‑amyloid/tau action to be 'disease‑targeted', a conservative reader might hesitate — but given the preventive/biomarker focus, 'disease‑targeted small molecule' is the best match. citeturn0search2turn0search0
Web search results used (summaries): FDA press release on VASCEPA (icosapent ethyl) approval and clinical context. citeturn0search0
VASCEPA 'How it Works' / product information confirming IPE is purified EPA and its intended clinical use and proposed mechanisms. citeturn0search2
Prescribing information / package insert describing IPE (VASCEPA) indications and formulation. citeturn0search3
Safety and product information page (adverse events, known risks). citeturn0search1
agent_type: C) ApoE, Lipids and Lipoprotein Receptors
explanation_agent: Reason: The trial drug is icosapent ethyl (IPE), an ethyl‑ester prodrug of the omega‑3 fatty acid eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA). Its primary pharmacology involves lipid modulation (reducing hepatic VLDL‑TG synthesis/secretion and enhancing TG clearance) with additional proposed anti‑inflammatory and vascular effects. citeturn0search2turn0search6

Act: Because IPE is a lipid (EPA) that acts on lipid metabolism / lipoprotein pathways and is used to alter cardiovascular and metabolic risk factors (and here is being tested to affect AD biomarkers/brain blood flow), the most specific CADRO match is C) ApoE, Lipids and Lipoprotein Receptors rather than categories focused on amyloid, tau, or solely inflammatory/neuroprotective mechanisms. citeturn0search5turn0search3

Reflect: This classification fits the description — the intervention is a lipid-based, disease‑targeted small molecule whose hypothesized benefit in preclinical AD relates to lipid/vascular and possibly anti‑inflammatory mechanisms. An alternative plausible classification could be F) Inflammation if the trial emphasized anti‑inflammatory action as the primary mechanism, but the drug’s established mechanism and indication center on lipids/lipoprotein biology, so C is the best fit. No evidence in the description indicates a direct amyloid/tau or synaptic receptor target. citeturn0search4turn0search1
Web search results used: DrugBank summary of icosapent ethyl (mechanism and metabolism). citeturn0search2
Web search results used: VASCEPA / Amarin product and dosing information (official site / HCP pages). citeturn0search0turn0search3
Web search results used: FDA / DailyMed prescribing information for VASCEPA (indications, formulation, safety). citeturn0search5
Web search results used: Medscape/clinical reference summary of mechanism and pharmacology. citeturn0search6
